By D. TEUFELSDROCKH
There has been a lot of shit flying around lately to the
effect that the Maryland House of Delegates (God Bless
Them)is all set to legalize dope,or at least really reduce
the penalties, or something good anyway. What a fine
daydream. Smoking dope with impunity, leering smugly .
as you blow smoke at the man, etc., etc.
And, unlike most of the wishful-thinking rumors that
go around, this one even has a vague foundation in reality.
Pretty vague, though. After a very hot summer (30 and
40 busts a month), there has been a noticeable decrease
In cannabis busts. The logical imputation is correct - Mandel, after making his point, has ordered the Baltimore
Police (who are under his direct control,not the Mayor's)
suspend grass and hash raiding.(That,by the way, does not
mean that if you get caught holding by accident you're off
the hook. You're busted.) A local political personality
even asserted that Mandel is surreptitiously backing the
liberals on the issue in Annapolis.
And here's the scoop-dope actually is an issue in Annapolis. Not much of an issue, to be sure. The opposition
is just about sure to blast it somewhere up into the
1990's.
Just for the record, though, there are three bills prefiled for the 1970 session of the General Assembly. The
most tepid of all is the usual deal about how more research
should be done on the subject.(sounds like one of those
cautious editorials in Time, yes?) To this end, Delegate
Jacobson is the sponsor of a bill "to request that the State
cooperate with the Federal Government in the funding and
development of research programs concerning marijuana
and hashish." Very big deal.
One guy, Sen. Stone by name, wants to give methadone
to smackheads. A more promising bill, filed by Senator
Bishop, provides that under certain circumstances, a

Edward J. Bagley, State Senator from Prince Georges County.
judge may exercise the option to reduce the charge to a
misdemeanor.(Now, it's a felony, with a mandatory sentence).
The most radical bill of all, and oddly enough, the one
with the best chance of getting passed, was prefiled in
December by one Del. Edward J. Bagley(D.,Prince Geo-

rge's County). Seems Prince George's (a more-thanaverage wealthy suburb of Washington) was getting a little
uptight about all these nicemiddleclass kids getting shafted. Charity starts in the home.The bill provides that "the
possession and use of marihuana shall be a misdemeanor...
(and) providing penalties therefore." The penalties,I was
informed, were $250 and/or 6 months for first offenders,
and double penalties for subsequent offenders.
On the whole, not a bad deal. For the time being, anyhow. And the best thing is that Bagley's bill has support
In the General Assembly. Maybe, even the Governor's.
Outasight! Utopia dawning.
Don't believe it for a minute. That bill is going to get
stomped, like a cockroach. The atmosphere in the Assembly is about as paranoid as it can get. One Delegate
Gerald J. Curran, reportedly made a speech against a
bill to lower the age at which one may sell his blood
without parental consent from 21 to 18, asserting that
young people would use the money to buy illegal drugs.
The bill to lower the voting age will probably get fewer
votes this year than last. A State Senator, who asked to
remain unnamed, said in an interview, "The attitude
of my colleagues in the Legislature is appaling....they're
Ignorant - they don't know what the kids are trying to tell
them. They talk to old people mostly, and old people are
tired of demonstrations. Some crazy amendments are being tacked on (to other bills) - like hang 'em in public."
Depressing, isn't it? I mean, everyone knows that
sooner or later, the government is going to have to accept
a few of the realities of the situation. But everyone also
knows that the government has to be pushed pretty hard
before it gets down to business. So far, nobody seems to
have done too much pushing.(Forgive the pun, it wasn't
intended) The other thing is, of course,that the Assembly
is populated largely by fossils. Don't worry,though,they'll
all be gone probably within thirty years or so.

Arab, Israeli Diplomats Come
Separately to Discuss Middle East
The Jordanian and Israeli ambassadors to the United
States and a high-ranking State Department official will
take part in a lecture series on the Middle East at The
Johns Hopkins University.
The first program will feature Abdul Hamid Sharaf,
ambassador of Jordan to the United States, who will speak
Wednesday at 4 p.m. in Shriver Hall on the University's
Homewood Campus. The program is open to the public
-without charge.
The Israeli ambassador, Yitzhak Rabin, will speak at
Johns Hopkins on March 12. Rodger P. Davies, U. S.
Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and
South Asian Affairs, will appear April 16.
Dean Wm Rudoy, a junior at Johns Hopkins, explained
that the series will provide a forum for the presentation of various policy perspectives concerning the Middle
East crisis.

"We would like the Israeli and Jordanian ambassadors
to outline their proposals for resolving the conflict, and
we hope that the representative of the United States will
indicate to what extent this country should be involved in
the Middle East," he said.
The lecture series is sponsored by the International
Forum, which was started two years ago by undergraduates to attract speakers on international affairs to Johns
Hopkins.

Student apathy is facing the organizers of the anti-Gordon Discipline Code
petition now in their third week of canvassing.
Jim Cleary, organizer of the undergraduate petition, said that he had "no
idea" if his group can garner enough
student signatures to fulfil the 25% quota
requested by President Gordon. So far,
a few hundred students have signed the
Petition out of the 2,000 undergraduates
on campus. The petition will be sent to
the President in the next few weeks.
Cleary stated that their main handicap
has been general disinterest in the Discipline Code. "Guys aren't taking any
Position at all," Cleary asserted."Most
of them haven't read either Gordon's,
the Student Affairs Committees' reports
or the News-Letter's account of the discipline issue."

What Ever Happened to•••
Almost one year ago to the day, Maryland public colleges and universities were ordered to desegregate their
facilities. Despite much law-and-order bantering on the
part of concerned local officials, the state has not complied, nor made any concete effort in the direction of
compliance.
The original order came down from the civil rights
division of HEW, which warned that non-compliance
would result in a loss of federal funds. Despite non-compliance, there has been no such loss. At the time of the
order—until last - week—the civil rights (i.e. enforcement)
division was headed by Mr. Leon Panetta. Last week, the
White House resigned Mr.Panetta, who was regarded as too
zealous for middle America on civil rights.
Panetta was reportedly the pawn in the latest of the
never-ending series of Nixon-Finch power struggles, which
Nixon invariably wins. This time Agnew had the gripe
from the White House side. It seemed to Agnew that
Panetta had diabolical plans to destroy white collegiate
sanctuaries in Agnew's own back yard, and possibly risk
exacerbating tensions by mixing the races.
•Despite recent Supreme Court rulings calling for immediate integration wherever segregation or de facto segregation is found, Maryland colleges—for that matter, Maryland
high schools--remain as they were a year ago, predominantly one-race institutions. The University of Maryland at
College Park, for example, was and is 99 per cent white.
Its Princess Anne County campus is 92 per cent black. And

zealous for middle America on civil rights.

never-ending series of Nixon-Finch power struggles, which
Nixon invariably wins. This time Agnew had the gripe

with its enforcement.

I was young then, still a freshman at
college, and I was in New York making
the rounds for a newspaper job. I went
first, of course, to the New York Times,
or, as I had come to call it, My Bible.
As I entered the building, I felt like
an aged, devout Moslem entering the holy
gates of Mecca.
Inside, everyone seemed to have slightly graying, razor-cut hair that modishly
came down over the collars of their
Van Ileusen shirts. Dressed in expensive, tailor-made pin stripe suits, they
chatted casually about yachting and polo,
and their tanned faced glowed with selfassurance. They had all graduated from
Harvard or the Columbia School of Journalism, or both.
Unfortunately, I was unable to get a job
at the Times, and with a shaky conscience, I took the cross-town bus to the
News.

Let's Crack Down!
Now, as a card-carrying Jewish liberal, I had always looked down on the
Daily News. I even used to cut out their
editorials and post them on my bulletin
board, in order to impress girls with
my wildly original,off-beat humor.Their
anti-dissent editorials usually went like
this:
It's high time that all these bleedingheart kooks and liberals quit their yapping about "police brutality." These
Commie dupes will go to no end in their
Kremlin-hatched smear job on the policemen of this nation. Along with the
softies on the Supreme Court, these
long-haired weirdoes are trying to handcuff the polico, while anarchists and
criminals are running wild on the streets.
We say let's put an end to all this hot
air on "criminal's rights," and start
thinking about the rights of the lawabiding citizens of the nation. The only
thing a criminal understands is a good
knock on the head, and pronto!

The Late Show
As I entered the city room of the News,
I rubbed my eyes in disbelief. The Daily
News was actually nothing more than a
re-creation of all the movies on newspapers that I had watched on the Late
Show. Everywhere I looked, old men in
suspenders, with their ties loosened,and
green, visors shading their eyes, were
beneover ancient black typewriters,fur-

iously pounding away. Elsewhere, reporters were making phone calls as they
nervously
smoked
cigarettes. Any
minute I expected Spencer Tracy or Humphrey Bogart to come in with the latest
scoop. I had always imagined that the
people who turned outthe copy must surely be a group of well-educated practical
jokers, turning out their drivel to mock
the sub-literate masses who so eagerly
gobbled it up.
This was not the case. The reporters
who told those millions of readers about
sexpot scandals and mad rapists were
really not that much different from their
readers.

Screw
But what was even more amazing to
me was the lack of status accorded even
the most illustrious editors. As I was
shown around the city room,occasionally
stopping to pick up a beer can that blocked my path, the personnel director pointed out various celebrities. "That's the
city editor," he said, pointing to a wizened, wrinkled old man in suspenders
who sat at the head of a large table ogling
the latest copy of Screw magazine.
"Hey", the old man exclaimed, "take a
look at that pussy!" The others at the
table looked up, and one aging man lumbered over to take a look for himself.
The city editor spread out the photo of a
hefty brunette model lifting her skirt.
We moved on to the other large desks,
and as he pointed out each one of the
various prominent people, I realized that
there was very little glamour about them.
In the Times, men in the same position
would have 'the fabulous aura of demigods. Here, however, they were just
men doing their jobs. They sat at
their desks like everybody else, and
they were not separated behind heavy
oak doors with gold letters on the outside. As I soon realized, although the
News may be more strident in its trumpetings against threats to the American
Way of Life, it was e4remely tolerant
within the bureaucratic structure.
The copyboys were almost all longhaired, except the black copyboys, who
were decked out in Afros, dashikis,
beads, or daz4ling silk shirts. On
weekends, reporters and copy editors
would come in T-shirts, blue jeans,
and bermuda shorts. The younger reporters were liberals, as were most of
the guys on the telegraph desk, and they
had a bemused attitude towards the

rantings in the editorial page.
